The other auth backend don't expose this issue. Does a "from flask_login import login_required, current_user, logout_user" in the auth_backend itself also solve the issue?

@bolkedebruin - default_login, kerberos_auth, and ldap_auth also have "lint" with:
`from flask_login import login_required, current_user, logout_user`
GitHub Auth **also works** with the above.

I guess my PR is a little overzealous bringing in a bit more than needed (basically reverted to the working version, plus the disable pylint message), adding `login_user` in addition to what the other auth schemes are brining in.

@jlowin so I am running your "queued-tasks" branch ... and seeing some weird issues around dag runs. don't have an extact handle on it yet... failed dag runs are getting created ... and I am now seeing dag runs created for 5 days prior to the start date.

I think the 5 day before thing is a known issue with the scheduler logic -- basically if you have a non-scheduled execution, the scheduler picks up 5 days before it. We will have to deal with that separately.
@jlowin  cool. I found the cause of the failing dag runs .. it was an unrelated issue. continuing to run this version today ... so far so good.

It sounds reasonable, we have to take a bit of time to think about the implications. 

Effectively it could also be implemented as an externally triggered DAG where the external trigger cares only about not having a current active DagRun. If that's what you need though it's nice to let the scheduler take care of it and not have to write and manage your own external trigger.

I think it's compatible with `depends_on_past=True` on "dealbreaker" task. Where if you want the flow to stop on error you can hook that up using the existing methodology.

It seems like it would be as easy as the code you sketched here.

@jlowin still trying to create a generic DAG to expose these bugs ... but wanted to let you know that it appears that the SDO operators that do not get updated do so when another task in the dag run has failed. 
1. Task Fails
2. Dag Run Fails
3. Subtasks complete
4. Status of SDOs remains running

Excellent, thanks so much for the feedback @syvineckruyk. I'm trying to figure out what in this code could have led to that behavior. I think it might be the extra `sync()` command I gave each executor. The idea was to avoid orphaned tasks by waiting for all tasks to complete -- but maybe there's a situation where the parent DAG has already quit before the orphaned tasks do... thinking further.

@jlowin just a question when I was running the last version you gave me.... things were running well ... what was the issue that required this area to need more work ?

```
commit fd9388c0c27c2e469f4eb0362800323a08b76d68
Merge: 58abca2 b2844af
Author: bolkedebruin <bolkedebruin@users.noreply.github.com>
Date:   Tue Apr 5 22:24:15 2016 +0200

    Merge pull request #1290 from jlowin/subdag-backfill-status

    Make sure backfill deadlocks raise errors

commit b2844af020cb5a470bd83ead09ddb121923084ca
Author: jlowin <jlowin@users.noreply.github.com>
Date:   Mon Apr 4 18:59:13 2016 -0400

    Fix infinite retries with pools, with test

    Addresses the issue raised in #1299

```

The issue you were experiencing was because Scheduler and Backfill were both trying to queue your SubDag tasks. The fix I put in place was that Scheduler kept track of tasks it submitted to the executor, and only tried to run _those_ tasks if they became queued. That way, the queued subdag tasks were left alone and Backfill handled them without interference. The problem is that folks often run Scheduler with the `--num_runs` parameter, which makes Scheduler restart periodically. When Scheduler restarts, it has no way to know what tasks it submitted before it quit, and so those tasks remain queued forever. The bug could occur less commonly if Scheduler were to quit for any other reason while tasks were queued.
ping @jbrownlucid

Great! Thanks @jlowin. Anyway if anyone see this PR useful enough to be merged in the codebase but considers that it is better to incorporate the feature in the config file we can change it easily anytime.

Hi @aadim , thanks for being the thorough with your description. It allowed my to dive in properly.

On why the scheduler starts the job 2016-04-24T00:00:00 (I am _not_ saying it is correct, I dont think it is). This is because the tasks in the DAG also get as start date "2016-04-24" and this is used to set the next_run_date in models.py:

```
                    # set start_date based on tasks
                    task_start_dates = [t.start_date for t in dag.tasks]
                    if task_start_dates:
                        next_run_date = min(task_start_dates)
                    else:
                        next_run_date = None
                    logging.info("Set next run date to {} based on task_start_date".format(next_run_date))
```

At the moment I, personally, think that next_run_date should be set to min(task_start_dates) + schedule_interval. What do you think @mistercrunch @jlowin ?

But when I run `./run_unit_tests.sh tests.core:HttpOpSensorTest.test_sensor -s --logging-level=DEBUG` on my local airflow, I get success. This is with python2.7 and python3.5.

Cool, wasn't familiar with `depends_on_past` but yeah, I think setting that on the sensor will work for protecting against infinite failed runs.  Thanks.

I agree it could be externally triggered if that is preferable...  I'd probably do it by having my DAG end with a node that fires the DAG again, effectively making it infinitely recursive (assuming it keeps on succeeding).  I believe I can do that on my own without needing to make any changes in core, so if that's the preferred method just let me know.

Actually, that might even be simpler.  The only downside I can see to it is that nothing in the way the job is scheduled would tell someone how it is being triggered.  They'd have to know about my special end-node on the DAG.  That's not the end of the world though.

https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/master/airflow/bin/cli.py#L830

https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/airbnb_1.7.1rc2/airflow/bin/cli.py#L644

https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/commit/6706babfd404173768b00f6add1b27d66d31a7e0

Code quality remained the same when pulling **[a5befa1](https://github.com/withnale/airflow/commit/a5befa1dad248b9ffc37fd69815e798e4011c687) on withnale:add_manual_trigger** into **[12b542d](https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/commit/12b542dacf003174e9d55ccebc40d81d3284fe60) on airbnb:master**.
Thanks for the contribution! Please add unit tests

Thanks @withnale. 

I have one concern that this will lead to unexpected DAG deadlocks, since the "manual" task will always report that its dependencies are unmet -- and a deadlock is defined as having unfinished tasks that are all unable to start due to dependencies being unmet. Therefore I suspect that this chain of events could happen:
1. scheduler happily runs tasks in the DAG up until it reaches the "manual" task
2. when the manual task is the only one left, the scheduler will think the DAG is deadlocked and mark the run (but not the task) as failed
3. later, the user comes along and triggers the manual task in the GUI 
4. the user is surprised that the manual tasks' downstream tasks don't run, but it's because the scheduler thinks the dagrun failed.

I think this might require a new task state (as in SUCCESS, FAILED, QUEUED) since it doesn't fit the current expectations of how tasks behave?

This issue can be fixed by replacing socket.gethostname() with socket.getfqdn()

Refer : http://stackoverflow.com/questions/20792499/how-to-get-fully-qualified-host-name-in-python

Also, even [Python docs](https://docs.python.org/2/library/socket.html) recommends using getfqdn over gethostname to fetch the hostname of the machine.

> socket.gethostname()
> Return a string containing the hostname of the machine where the Python interpreter is currently executing. If you want to know the current machines IP address, you may want to use gethostbyname(gethostname()). This operation assumes that there is a valid address-to-host mapping for the host, and the assumption does not always hold.Note: gethostname() doesnt always return the fully qualified domain name; use getfqdn() (see above).
